#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Chapter II .
#Text=The Law of Club and Fang
#Text=Buck ’s first day on the Dyea beach was like a nightmare .
#Text=Every hour was filled with shock and surprise .
#Text=He had been suddenly jerked from the heart of civilization and flung into the heart of things primordial .
#Text=No lazy , sun-kissed life was this , with nothing to do but loaf and be bored .
#Text=Here was neither peace , nor rest , nor a moment ’s safety .
#Text=All was confusion and action , and every moment life and limb were in peril .
#Text=There was imperative need to be constantly alert ; for these dogs and men were not town dogs and men .
#Text=They were savages , all of them , who knew no law but the law of club and fang .
#Text=He had never seen dogs fight as these wolfish creatures fought , and his first experience taught him an unforgetable lesson .
#Text=It is true , it was a vicarious experience , else he would not have lived to profit by it .
#Text=Curly was the victim .
#Text=They were camped near the log store , where she , in her friendly way , made advances to a husky dog the size of a full-grown wolf , though not half so large as she .
#Text=There was no warning , only a leap in like a flash , a metallic clip of teeth , a leap out equally swift , and Curly ’s face was ripped open from eye to jaw .
#Text=It was the wolf manner of fighting , to strike and leap away ; but there was more to it than this .
#Text=Thirty or forty huskies ran to the spot and surrounded the combatants in an intent and silent circle .
#Text=Buck did not comprehend that silent intentness , nor the eager way with which they were licking their chops .
#Text=Curly rushed her antagonist , who struck again and leaped aside .
#Text=He met her next rush with his chest , in a peculiar fashion that tumbled her off her feet .
#Text=She never regained them , This was what the onlooking huskies had waited for .
#Text=They closed in upon her , snarling and yelping , and she was buried , screaming with agony , beneath the bristling mass of bodies .
#Text=So sudden was it , and so unexpected , that Buck was taken aback .
#Text=He saw Spitz run out his scarlet tongue in a way he had of laughing ; and he saw François , swinging an axe , spring into the mess of dogs .
#Text=Three men with clubs were helping him to scatter them .
#Text=It did not take long .
#Text=Two minutes from the time Curly went down , the last of her assailants were clubbed off .
#Text=But she lay there limp and lifeless in the bloody , trampled snow , almost literally torn to pieces , the swart half-breed standing over her and cursing horribly .
#Text=The scene often came back to Buck to trouble him in his sleep .
#Text=So that was the way .
#Text=No fair play .
#Text=Once down , that was the end of you .
#Text=Well , he would see to it that he never went down .
#Text=Spitz ran out his tongue and laughed again , and from that moment Buck hated him with a bitter and deathless hatred .
#Text=Before he had recovered from the shock caused by the tragic passing of Curly , he received another shock .
#Text=François fastened upon him an arrangement of straps and buckles .
#Text=It was a harness , such as he had seen the grooms put on the horses at home .
#Text=And as he had seen horses work , so he was set to work , hauling François on a sled to the forest that fringed the valley , and returning with a load of firewood .
#Text=Though his dignity was sorely hurt by thus being made a draught animal , he was too wise to rebel .
#Text=He buckled down with a will and did his best , though it was all new and strange .

#Text=François was stern , demanding instant obedience , and by virtue of his whip receiving instant obedience ; while Dave , who was an experienced wheeler , nipped Buck ’s hind quarters whenever he was in error .

#Text=Spitz was the leader , likewise experienced , and while he could not always get at Buck , he growled sharp reproof now and again , or cunningly threw his weight in the traces to jerk Buck into the way he should go .
#Text=Buck learned easily , and under the combined tuition of his two mates and François made remarkable progress .

#Text=Ere they returned to camp he knew enough to stop at “ ho , ” to go ahead at “ mush , ” to swing wide on the bends , and to keep clear of the wheeler when the loaded sled shot downhill at their heels .
#Text=“ T’ree vair ’ good dogs , ” François told Perrault .
#Text=“ Dat Buck , heem pool lak hell .
#Text=I tich heem queek as anyt’ing . ”
#Text=By afternoon , Perrault , who was in a hurry to be on the trail with his despatches , returned with two more dogs .
#Text=“ Billee ” and “ Joe ” he called them , two brothers , and true huskies both .
#Text=Sons of the one mother though they were , they were as different as day and night .
#Text=Billee ’s one fault was his excessive good nature , while Joe was the very opposite , sour and introspective , with a perpetual snarl and a malignant eye .
#Text=Buck received them in comradely fashion , Dave ignored them , while Spitz proceeded to thrash first one and then the other .
#Text=Billee wagged his tail appeasingly , turned to run when he saw that appeasement was of no avail , and cried ( still appeasingly ) when Spitz ’s sharp teeth scored his flank .

#Text=But no matter how Spitz circled , Joe whirled around on his heels to face him , mane bristling , ears laid back , lips writhing and snarling , jaws clipping together as fast as he could snap , and eyes diabolically gleaming — the incarnation of belligerent fear .

#Text=So terrible was his appearance that Spitz was forced to forego disciplining him ; but to cover his own discomfiture he turned upon the inoffensive and wailing Billee and drove him to the confines of the camp .
